name: Union Square Park
summary: Public square opened 1839; by 1852 a residential promenade.
description: Laid out and opened in 1839, Union Square Park was a fenced oval with radiating walks and new plantings. By 1852 it anchored an elite residential district and hosted civic gatherings.
address_hint: 14th–17th St, Union Sq West/East, Union Square, Union Square
sources: [{"title": "Union Square Park \u2014 History", "publisher": "NYC Parks", "url": "https://www.nycgovparks.org/parks/union-square-park/history"}, {"title": "Union Square, Manhattan", "publisher": "Wikipedia", "url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_Square,_Manhattan"}]

name: Croton Fountain (Union Square)
summary: Central fountain fed by the Croton Aqueduct (installed 1842).
description: A fountain in the center of Union Square was connected to the new Croton Aqueduct in October 1842. In 1852 it remained a prominent feature, symbolizing the city’s modern water supply.
address_hint: Union Square Park (center), Union Square, Union Square
sources: [{"title": "Union Square, Manhattan \u2014 Croton fountain note", "publisher": "Wikipedia", "url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_Square,_Manhattan#Development"}, {"title": "Croton Fountain 1842\u20131870 (marker text)", "publisher": "HMdb.org", "url": "https://www.hmdb.org/m.asp?m=130147"}, {"title": "History of fountains in the United States \u2014 Croton Aqueduct", "publisher": "Wikipedia", "url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_fountains_in_the_United_States"}]
images: [{"url": "https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Croton_Fountain,_New_York_X_703.jpeg", "credit": "Public domain engraving of Croton-era fountain (Wikimedia Commons)", "license": "Public Domain"}]

name: 862–866 Broadway Rowhouses
summary: Surviving 1840s rowhouses at the north edge of Union Square.
description: These three- and four‑story brick rowhouses at 862–866 Broadway, present by the 1840s, are cited as surviving remnants of Union Square’s early residential phase and stood here in 1852.
address_hint: Broadway between E 17th & E 18th St, Union Square, Union Square
sources: [{"title": "Union Square \u2014 early rowhouses 862\u2013866 Broadway", "publisher": "Wikipedia", "url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_Square,_Manhattan#Development"}]
images: [{"url": "https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:862-872_Broadway.jpg", "credit": "Beyond My Ken (Wikimedia Commons), photo of 862\u2013872 Broadway", "license": "CC-BY-SA"}]

name: Madison Square Park
summary: Public park opened May 10, 1847; a social hub by 1852.
description: Opened in 1847, Madison Square Park was an elegant public space by 1852, soon to be surrounded by hotels and clubs as development pushed uptown.
address_hint: 5th Ave to Madison Ave, 23rd–26th St, Flatiron District, Flatiron District
sources: [{"title": "Madison Square Park \u2014 History", "publisher": "NYC Parks", "url": "https://www.nycgovparks.org/parks/madison-square-park/history"}]

name: Madison Cottage (road house)
summary: Stagecoach inn at Broadway & 23rd (1839–1852), razed in 1852.
description: A farmhouse-turned-roadhouse named for President Madison, Madison Cottage sat at Broadway & 23rd and served travelers. It was demolished in 1852, soon replaced by Franconi’s Hippodrome and later the Fifth Avenue Hotel.
address_hint: Broadway & E 23rd St (Madison Square), Flatiron District, Flatiron District
sources: [{"title": "Madison Cottage \u2014 history note", "publisher": "Flatiron/23rd Street Partnership", "url": "https://flatironnomad.nyc/history/madison-cottage/"}, {"title": "Madison Square & Park \u2014 early history (1852 image reference)", "publisher": "Wikipedia", "url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madison_Square_and_Madison_Square_Park"}, {"title": "Madison Cottage \u2014 1852 engraving", "publisher": "Geographic Guide (NYPL image)", "url": "https://www.geographicguide.com/united-states/nyc/antique/madison-square/19th-century/madison-cottage.htm"}]
images: [{"url": "https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Madison_Cottage.jpg", "credit": "Wikimedia Commons (NYPL provenance) \u2014 Madison Cottage illustration", "license": "Public Domain"}]

name: Free Academy (City College precursor)
summary: James Renwick Jr.’s Gothic Revival Free Academy opened 1849.
description: At Lexington Ave & E 23rd St, the Free Academy (opened 1849) was the city’s pioneering public higher‑education institution; in 1852 its ivy‑clad building was an educational landmark in this district.
block: SE corner Lexington Ave & E 23rd St
address_hint: SE corner Lexington Ave & E 23rd St, Flatiron District, Flatiron District
sources: [{"title": "CUNY \u2014 Origins and Formative Years (Free Academy opens 1849)", "publisher": "City University of New York", "url": "https://www.cuny.edu/about/history/origins-and-formative-years/"}, {"title": "City College of New York \u2014 History & Downtown campus", "publisher": "Wikipedia", "url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_College_of_New_York"}, {"title": "Free Academy photo (PD)", "publisher": "Wikimedia Commons", "url": "https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Freeacad.jpg"}]

name: Equestrian Statue of George Washington
summary: H.K. Brown bronze equestrian statue (ded. 1856).
description: By 1877 Henry Kirke Brown’s equestrian statue of George Washington stood at the south end of Union Square, a focal point for civic gatherings and parades.
address_hint: 14th St plaza (south end), Union Square, Union Square

name: Statue of Abraham Lincoln
summary: Henry Kirke Brown bronze statue (ded. 1870).
description: Henry Kirke Brown’s standing bronze of Abraham Lincoln was installed in 1870 on the north side of Union Square; it remained a prominent monument by 1877.
block: North side of Union Square Park
address_hint: North side of Union Square Park, Union Square, Union Square

name: Statue of Marquis de Lafayette
summary: Bartholdi bronze (gift of France, 1876).
description: Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi’s statue of the Marquis de Lafayette, installed in 1876, stood on Union Square’s east side in 1877, marking Franco‑American ties.
address_hint: East side near 16th St, Union Square, Union Square

name: Statue of Liberty Arm & Torch (exhibit)
summary: Liberty’s forearm & torch displayed in Madison Square Park (1876–1882) for fundraising.
description: To raise funds for the pedestal, the Statue of Liberty’s forearm and torch were exhibited in Madison Square Park from 1876 into the early 1880s; visitors could climb the torch. In 1877 it was a headline attraction.
address_hint: Madison Square Park (central lawn), Flatiron District, Flatiron District
sources: [{"title": "Statue of Liberty \u2014 Early fundraising exhibitions", "publisher": "Wikipedia", "url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty#Fund-raising_and_assembly"}, {"title": "Madison Square Park \u2014 History timeline (torch exhibit)", "publisher": "Madison Square Park Conservancy", "url": "https://madisonsquarepark.org/park/about-the-park/"}]

name: Statue of William H. Seward
summary: Randolph Rogers bronze (ded. 1876) in Madison Square Park.
description: The bronze statue of Secretary of State William Henry Seward by Randolph Rogers was unveiled in 1876 near the park’s southwest corner; by 1877 it drew crowds in the busy square.
address_hint: Madison Square Park (SW corner), Flatiron District, Flatiron District
sources: [{"title": "Statue of William Henry Seward \u2014 MSPC page", "publisher": "Madison Square Park Conservancy", "url": "https://madisonsquarepark.org/art/statue-of-william-henry-seward/"}, {"title": "Statue of William Henry Seward", "publisher": "Wikipedia", "url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statue_of_William_Henry_Seward_(New_York_City)"}]

name: Fifth Avenue Hotel
summary: Luxury hotel at 200 Fifth Ave (opened 1859; a social center by 1877).
description: The Fifth Avenue Hotel, opened 1859 at Fifth Ave & 23rd St, was one of the city’s premier hotels; in 1877 it dominated Madison Square with political and society events.
address_hint: 200 Fifth Ave (NW corner at 23rd), Flatiron District, Flatiron District

name: Union Square Park
summary: Historic civic plaza with monuments and promenades.
description: By 1902 Union Square Park was an established civic square, known for public gatherings and 19th‑century monuments such as Washington and Lafayette. The park’s role as a rally site and promenade continued into the new century.

summary: Century‑old triangular skyscraper and district icon.
description: In 2002 the 1902 Flatiron Building remained an iconic landmark at Fifth Avenue, Broadway, and 23rd Street, housing offices and retail.
address_hint: 175 Fifth Ave (E 22nd–23rd), Flatiron District, Flatiron District

name: Madison Square Park (renovated)
summary: Major restoration completed around 2001; art program launches.
description: By 2002, the park’s restoration had revived lawns, paths, and monuments and laid groundwork for contemporary public‑art programming.
address_hint: 5th Ave (E 23rd–26th), Flatiron District, Flatiron District

name: Metropolitan Life Insurance Company Tower
summary: Clock‑tower skyscraper still defining the skyline.
description: The 1909 Met Life Tower continued to dominate the east side of the park in 2002, with its clock faces and campanile form a neighborhood beacon.
address_hint: 1 Madison Ave (E 23rd & Madison), Flatiron District, Flatiron District
